newsitem.title: USA: NYCE cotton ends barely down on producer selling.
newsitem.headline: NYCE cotton ends barely down on producer selling.

text.p: Producer selling at the highs limited this week's rally of NYCE cotton futures and pushed the benchmark March contract slightly below unchanged by the close.
Dealers said trade selling emerged at 75.00 cents a lb in March, and local selling added pressure to the downward slide.
Fund shortcovering sparked early gains and lifted benchmark March to a high of 75.25 cents, traders said. The contract ended off 0.05 at 74.60 cents after trading from 75.25 to 74.35 cents.
The back months settled 0.25 lower to 0.23 firmer.
Resistance was seen at 75.00 for March cotton, under which steady trade selling is expected to pressure the March contract, and support at 73.00 cents.
The market brushed off bullish reports by USDA and U.S. Census Bureau as the data had already been built into prices earlier this week.
"The reports were close enough to what was expected that we can't attribute them to (early) gains," a dealer said.
USDA put new sales in the 1996/97 crop at 221,000 lots, for the week ended Jan 16.
Census Bureau reported December mill consumption at 849,786 bales, or 10,322,212 bales in 1996. These numbers compare with 800,605 bales for December 1995 and 10,409,286 bales in 1995.
